properties.description: Not Applicable (no global hypothesis specified for this run)
Defeat of France in the French and Indian War
British Parliament imposed new taxes on colonies
British officials in Montreal took control of colonies' western lands
British national debt grown to £133 million after French and Indian War
Cost of stationing 10,000 soldiers in North America
Grenville believed colonies should help pay troop costs
Parliament passed the Sugar Act (decreased duties, stricter enforcement)
Grenville proposed direct taxes on colonies to raise revenue
Parliament passed the Stamp Act (imposed first direct taxes)
Grievance: Taxation without representation violated rights as Englishmen
Sons of Liberty formed
properties.timestamp: Shortly following adoption of Stamp Act

properties.description: Sons of Liberty used public demonstrations, boycotts, threats of violence
British tax laws became unenforceable
Sons of Liberty in Boston burned vice admiralty court records and looted Thomas Hutchinson's home
Stamp Act Congress convened (representatives from 9 colonies)
Declaration of Rights and Grievances drawn up
Congress organized a boycott on imports of all British merchandise
Process by which colonists resisted British policies and made them unenforceable or caused their repeal.
Parliament saw itself as supreme lawmaking authority throughout the Empire
Parliament believed it was entitled to levy any tax without colonial approval
Colonies were legally British corporations subordinate to the British Parliament
Parliament argued colonists had 'virtual representation'
Americans like James Otis maintained no one in Parliament was responsible to a colonial constituency
Benjamin Franklin made case for Stamp Act repeal to Parliament
Franklin argued further taxes after war contributions were unjust and might cause rebellion
Parliament repealed the Stamp Act
Parliament insisted in Declaratory Act they retained full power to make laws for colonies
Widespread celebrations in the colonies following Stamp Act repeal
British Parliament passed the Townshend Acts (duties on goods, Board of Customs)
Parliament's goal with Townshend Acts was to assert authority, not primarily collect revenue
New taxes enacted on belief Americans only objected to internal taxes
John Dickinson's Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania published
Dickinson argued Townshend Acts were unconstitutional because purpose was revenue, not trade regulation
Colonists responded to Townshend Acts by organizing new boycotts
Massachusetts Assembly issued a circular letter urging coordinated resistance
Governor dissolved the assembly when it refused to rescind the circular letter
Riot broke out in Boston over seizure of the sloop Liberty (owned by John Hancock)
Customs officials were forced to flee Boston
British deployed troops to Boston
Boston town meeting declared no obedience was due to parliamentary laws and called for convention
A convention assembled but only issued a mild protest before dissolving
Parliament reactivated the Treason Act 1543 (trials in England for treason outside realm)
Governor of Massachusetts instructed to collect evidence of treason
Threat of Treason Act caused widespread outrage in colonies
Large crowd gathered around British soldiers on Boston street
Crowd grew threatening, throwing snowballs, rocks, and debris
One British soldier was clubbed and fell
British soldiers panicked and fired into the crowd
Boston Massacre: 11 people hit, 5 civilians died
Soldiers were tried and acquitted (defended by John Adams)
Widespread descriptions of Boston Massacre turned colonial sentiment against the British
Accelerated downward spiral in relationship between Britain and Massachusetts
Parliament repealed most Townshend duties, except tax on tea
Crisis temporarily resolved, boycott largely ceased

properties.name: Samuel Adams
properties.role: Radical Patriot, leader of Sons of Liberty

properties.description: More radical patriots like Samuel Adams continued to agitate
American patriots burned HMS Gaspee (British warship enforcing trade regulations)
Gaspee affair investigated for possible treason
No action taken following Gaspee investigation
Private letters of Massachusetts Governor Thomas Hutchinson published
Hutchinson claimed colonists could not enjoy all English liberties and called for direct payment of officials
Letters' contents used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
Hutchinson discredited in the eyes of the people
Colonial Assembly petitioned for Hutchinson's recall
Benjamin Franklin removed from Postmaster General position after leaking letters
Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence
Committees of Correspondence linked Patriots in all 13 colonies and provided framework for rebel government
Parliament passed the Tea Act (lowered price of taxed tea, special consignees)
Tea Act opposed by those resisting taxes and smugglers losing business
Demonstrators warned merchants not to bring in tea with tax
In most instances, consignees forced to resign and tea turned back
Massachusetts governor Hutchinson refused to allow Boston merchants to give in to pressure
Boston town meeting determined tea would not be landed, ignored governor demand to disperse
Group led by Samuel Adams dumped £10,000 worth of tea into Boston Harbor
Opposition to Tea Act driven by smugglers losing business
Opposition to Tea Act driven by resistance to taxes
British government responded to Boston Tea Party
British government passed four laws known as the Intolerable Acts
Massachusetts Government Act (altered charter, restricted town meetings)
Administration of Justice Act (British soldiers tried in Britain, not colonies)
Boston Port Act (closed port until tea paid for)
Quartering Act of 1774 (royal governors house troops in homes)
Intolerable Acts further darkened colonial opinion towards England
Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves
Alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress formed
Provincial Congress began training militia outside British-occupied Boston
First Continental Congress convened (representatives from 12 colonies)
Committees coordinated Patriot resistance through underground networks
Battles of Lexington and Concord
American Revolutionary War launched
Second Continental Congress convened
Second Continental Congress formed the Continental Army
George Washington appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army
Washington and Continental Army responded by surrounding Boston
British forced to withdraw from Boston by sea
Patriots left in control in every colony
King George III proclaimed Massachusetts in state of open defiance and rebellion
Second Continental Congress began debating and deliberating on Articles of Confederation
Lee Resolution passed, affirming support for national independence

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson
properties.role: Primary author of Declaration of Independence

properties.description: Declaration of Independence unanimously adopted by Second Continental Congress
Process by which a unique American identity developed separate from British identity.
British policy of salutary neglect over first 150 years
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs
British policy changed significantly after French and Indian War
Thirteen Colonies sought greater autonomy from Britain
English Civil War and its aftermath
Puritan colonies of New England supported the Commonwealth government
Massachusetts did not recognize Charles II as legitimate king for over a year after restoration
New England colonies fought King Philip's War without military assistance from England
Charles and James II attempted to bring New England under direct English control
Colonists fiercely opposed attempts at direct control
Crown nullified colonial charters in response to opposition
James finalized efforts by consolidating colonies into Dominion of New England

properties.name: Edmund Andros
properties.role: Royal governor of Dominion of New England

properties.description: Dominion rule restricted colonial assemblies/town meetings, levied new taxes, abridged rights
Dominion rule triggered bitter resentment throughout New England
James II tried to rule without Parliament
English aristocracy removed James II from power in Glorious Revolution
1689 Boston revolt followed Glorious Revolution
Dominion rule overthrown by Boston revolt
Colonial governments reasserted their control after revolt
New monarchs granted new charters to individual New England colonies
Local democratic self-government restored in New England
British constitution with guarantees of rights of Englishmen
Radical Whig ideology with love of liberty and opposition to tyranny
American spokesmen propounded 'republicanism'
Economic policy of mercantilism and its effects on colonial trade and industry, leading to political friction.
British government pursued a policy of mercantilism
Parliament passed the first in a series of Navigation Acts
Navigation Acts restricted colonial trade with foreign countries
Any European imports bound for British America had to first pass through an English port and pay customs duties
Other laws regulated colonial industries (Wool Act, Hat Act, Iron Act)
Molasses Act 1733 placed duty on foreign molasses
Molasses Act protested by New England colonists as taxation without representation
Molasses Act increased smuggling of foreign molasses
British government ceased enforcement efforts after the 1740s (Molasses Act)
Limits on foreign-built ships greatly benefitted colonial shipbuilding industry
Political friction triggered by Navigation Acts and other trade laws, particularly among merchants
Some argue economic impact of trade restrictions was minimal on colonists
British government lacked resources and information needed to control the colonies
British officials negotiated and compromised with colonial leaders to gain compliance
Colonies defended themselves with colonial militias
British government rarely sent military forces to America before 1755
Americans had become almost completely self-governing before the American Revolution (Middlekauff)
Practice of self-governance was consistent with salutary neglect
During FIW, colonies contributed money, manpower, blood
Two-fifths of colonial FIW spending reimbursed by British government
Great Britain acquired France's territory east of Mississippi River
Bute ministry decided to permanently garrison 10,000 soldiers in North America
Garrison allowed officers to remain on pay, provided defense, prevented conflict with Natives, helped collect duties
Stationing a standing army in Great Britain during peacetime was politically unacceptable
Migration beyond Appalachian Mountains increased after French threat removed
Native Americans launched Pontiac's War in response to migration
Grenville ministry issued Royal Proclamation of 1763 (Indian Reserve closed to white settlement)
Proclamation failed to stop westward migration
Proclamation angered settlers, fur traders, and land speculators in the Thirteen Colonies
Process by which colonies moved from resistance to formally declaring independence.
Military and political process that led to Britain negotiating an end to the war and recognizing independence.
The Revolutionary War continued
France ultimately entered the war, supporting the colonial cause
Washington, with French support, led decisive victory in Siege of Yorktown
Roughly 7,500 British troops led by Cornwallis captured during Siege of Yorktown
Victory at Yorktown led to collapse of King George's control of Parliament
Consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms
King George III and the British negotiated an end to colonial rule in the colonies
The British signed the Treaty of Paris, acknowledging independence and granting territory
Independence of the United States of America from Great Britain codified
Establishment of the sovereign United States of America
About 60,000 Loyalists migrated to other British territories
The United States became the first constitutional republic in world history founded on consent of the governed and rule of law
